Asif Sattar wrote:

>createLogFile() is private static because I want there to
>be only one instance of the logger class , the class
>createLogFile() belongs to (it's a singleton).
>
>--- Kevin Lawrence <kevin@...> wrote:
>
>  
>
>>1. Why is createLogFile() private static ?
>>
>>If it were a public non-static method called create() in
>>a class called, 
>>say, LogFile, you could separate the file creation from
>>the stream 
>>handling and test each independently.
>>
>>2. A common technique is to wrap the date handling in a
>>class which you 
>>can then manipulate in your test.
>>
>>Kevin
>>    
>>

by making the createLogFile static, it becomes a Class method - it is 
not bound to any Instance (i.e. object) of that class type- regardless 
of the class being a Singleton.

If the Class is a singleton, then all methods apart from the 
'getInstance()' should be non static methods.

As for the testability, as JB stated, you can pass one in.

The Singleton nature of the Logger class, does not have to mean we can't 
change where it logs to. By passing in our own Stream we can change 
where and how the logs are logged, without having to change the 
Singleton Logger class.

so, create an instance method like 'public void 
setOutputStream(OutputStream os)'

then in your tests you can set it to a fake outputstream which your 
tests can use to verify that the Singleton works as expected.

HTH
